Career Management Document - Features, Accomplishments, and Benefits

F.A.B. stands for Features, Accomplishments and Benefits. It's a recruiting tool to guide the design of a resume for a particular company. Features are the high level information. Accomplishments expound on that with some specific examples. Benefits are what would appeal to the company. What's in it for them?

Features Accomplishments Benefits
Consultant
  • 3 Years as on-site consultant
  • 4 years as off-site consultant
  • 10 years as freelance consultant
  • Familiarity with working remotely
  • Ability to adapt to new and unfamiliar projects and technologies
  • Understand the requirements of a consulting position
  • Personable
  • Understand the needs of clients and how to answer their questions
Web developer
  • Built first website in 1994
  • Blogger since 2000
  • Wordpress user since 2002?
  • A lot of experience in structuring HTML and CSS. By hand.
  • Semantic page design
  • Understanding blogging, social media et al
Project Management Managed multiple projects from conception to deployment Experience
Programming
  • Ruby on Rails
  • HTML/CSS
  • jQuery
  • C# and VB.NET
  • Understand multiple programming languages, the purposes, strengths and weaknesses of each
Project Estimation
  • Estimated multiple projects to determine scope and cost
  • Can estimate projects
  • Help prepare scope of work documents for clients
  • Win business
Testing Manual and automated testing of software Ensure code quality
Requirements gathering Gather requirements for new projects
Human Resource management
  • Interviewed and hired developers
  • Assigned work
  • Assessed performance and wrote reviews
  • Understanding of human resource management
Trendsetter
  • Introduced object-oriented design to two companies
  • Introduced unit testing to a company
  • Looking for ways to build software better, faster and cheaper
  • Understanding of the software marketplace and new technologies
Written Skills
  • Blogger
  • Fiction writer
  • Documentation
  • Produce helpful user documentation
  • Write proposals and estimates to win business
  • Educate clients about software development

Some random thoughts

I am a Chicago-based freelance software developer.

I have run my own company for the past ten years.

I check in with my customers with regular weekly status reports, and sooner if its required.

Nearly all of my client work has been done remotely.

I love to create software that excites users and they wonder how they lived without it.

I've built several apps using Ruby on Rails. I haven't dug into the details of Ember yet, but that's on the roadmap.

I'm a hardcore hand-editing html and css guy since the mid-1990s. I like javascript, but often turn to jQuery because its so easy to use.

The applications I've built in Rails have either used MySQL or PostgreSQL, but I'm also quite familiar with SQL through years of using SQL Server on the Microsoft development platform.

Final scope was deployed to Heroku

RSpec? Love it! Cucumber tests too. I pushed one of my jobs to use unit testing.

I'm familiar with Spree, but haven't done any work with it.

I've worked on teams of all sizes, both in person and remotely.

I know communication is important when working with a team, so I'll use any means necessary including email, chat, forums and smoke signals.

Ship fast? ugh?

In every role I have ever had, I've looked for ways to improve processes and products. This has been as simple as requiring developers to use source control (back in the day), to test-driven development as well object oriented

Fun? I don't believe in fun. Or sombreros.

I love consulting because of the ever-changing landscape of tools and technologies. Only in a consulting role does a software developer get thrown in to try new tools and find the solutions that solve problems.

Agile:

Individuals and interactions over processes and tools

Working software over comprehensive documentation.

Customer collaboration over contract negotiation

Responding to change over following a plan

## Aug 2018 - May 2019: IT Manager, iD Commerce + Logistics

Mark Pell, Chief Operating Officer

Accountable for all technical delivery for ID Logistics. This includes project management, support, development and innovation. Leader and hiring manager for department. Key skills and accomplishments include;
_ Improved the reputation of department from burden to trusted and essential partner. This was accomplished by building strong relationships throughout the company, effectively communicating timelines, deliverables and limitations.
_ Delivered technical excellence in development. by enforcing code standards, conducting peer code reviews and leading training sessions to facilitate knowledge sharing and clean code practices.
_ Created tangible valuable for the business by paying down technical debt and rewriting core libraries. Eliminated production errors and reduced the code base by ~80 percent. Reduced client onboarding time from more than 20 days to less than 1 day.  
 _ Improved customer experience by integrating additional delivery vendors to meet customer needs. Improved reliability by organizing a chaotic development process to include semantic versioning, source control, test-driven development and business rule documentation.
_ Provide leadership to the executive team by setting the direction and solutions available to improve customer experience, efficiency and profitability. Support operations and seek opportunities to reduce workload through automation.
_ Ensure success for employees by coaching and providing feedback through regular coaching sessions and performance reviews. Schedule the work for the department so team members are clear on expectations and are able to focus on high priority items.
_ Recruit and develop top talent to further the success of the department and continue developing a servant leadership culture. Having the opportunity to both lead and act as a developer allows me to advance the skill-sets of my employees in a tangible and efficient way. I am able to lead by example.  
 _ Transitioned the IT organization through a corporate acquisition. Conducted documentation, gap analysis and integration plans to ensure best transitions. Invited to help on larger projects for the parent company.

Industries: Third-party logistics, eCommerce
